update.description:
This makes plugins with collapsible configurable properties look similar to those without.

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/1920485605-flat_button_after.png)
‌

Without this change, some stylesheets were looking different:

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/3724459758-flat_button_before.png)
‌

‌

I also removed the 0-sized margins around the Displays widget so that its padding is similar to other widgets e.g. Topic viewer and Scene tree.
update.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw: I’ve definitely learnt a lot about QSS today so I’m happy you made the suggestion :smiley: I see the concern that then it might not behave as people expect.. do you think it would it be useful to put something in style.qss that doesn’t modify anything but is just a comment about the fact that setFlat is being called on those buttons programmatically? \(Or would it just be strange\)
content.html: I’ve definitely learnt a lot about QSS today so I’m happy you made the suggestion I see the concern that then it might not behave as people expect.. do you think it would it be useful to put something in style.qss that doesn’t modify anything but is just a comment about the fact that setFlat is being called on those buttons programmatically? (Or would it just be strange)

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw:
I totally agree with you that putting it in the QSS makes the plugin less self-contained and feels like bad design.

My main worry is that having this hardcoded in the C++ code could lead to undesired effects when someone *does* choose to add some QSS on top of it. I've had problems setting other such properties before, and by looking at [questions like this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/34654801/6451468), I suspect the `flat` property can cause problems down the road. Based on these experiences, I've sort of defaulted to the "best practice" of leaving all styling responsibilities to the QSS.

One thing that I've thought about before and I think could address the concerns here, was allowing plugins to have their own stylesheets, instead of relying on a single global sheet. But that will probably never happen...

In any case, this was mainly a suggestion and a heads up in case you run into styling issues with this button in the future. Feel free to leave the implementation like this :wink:
content.html:
I totally agree with you that putting it in the QSS makes the plugin less self-contained and feels like bad design.

My main worry is that having this hardcoded in the C++ code could lead to undesired effects when someone does choose to add some QSS on top of it. I've had problems setting other such properties before, and by looking at questions like this, I suspect the flat property can cause problems down the road. Based on these experiences, I've sort of defaulted to the "best practice" of leaving all styling responsibilities to the QSS.

One thing that I've thought about before and I think could address the concerns here, was allowing plugins to have their own stylesheets, instead of relying on a single global sheet. But that will probably never happen...

In any case, this was mainly a suggestion and a heads up in case you run into styling issues with this button in the future. Feel free to leave the implementation like this

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw:
The last point is what I was questioning. It seems less self-contained… Let me explain what I’m thinking and then we can decide which way to go :slight_smile:   
  
The part that the display widgets' collapsible should be set to match those that do not have expandable properties seems "internal" to the implementation of the Displays widget \(caused by the fact that some displays are shown in buttons and some aren't\). Doing it programmatically \(with `setFlat`\) means that all users of the Displays widget will have that visual consistency "for free"; custom stylesheet or not. But doing it in the qss means that anyone that wants to customise the default qss also has to carry this property into their qss file, not because they are customising it, but just because it's needed to make the Displays widget look right.

I am with you that we can go either way technically, just not sure which is the better approach design-wise. Perhaps it is not appropriate for us to decide what is “right” for the display, and so it should be done in qss so that users can avoid it if they like, but it seems like unnecessary extra work for everyone else if we go that way
content.html:
The last point is what I was questioning. It seems less self-contained… Let me explain what I’m thinking and then we can decide which way to go

The part that the display widgets' collapsible should be set to match those that do not have expandable properties seems "internal" to the implementation of the Displays widget (caused by the fact that some displays are shown in buttons and some aren't). Doing it programmatically (with setFlat) means that all users of the Displays widget will have that visual consistency "for free"; custom stylesheet or not. But doing it in the qss means that anyone that wants to customise the default qss also has to carry this property into their qss file, not because they are customising it, but just because it's needed to make the Displays widget look right.

I am with you that we can go either way technically, just not sure which is the better approach design-wise. Perhaps it is not appropriate for us to decide what is “right” for the display, and so it should be done in qss so that users can avoid it if they like, but it seems like unnecessary extra work for everyone else if we go that way

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw:
> if a .config xml file has a stylesheet specified in it (with properties for collapsibleButton, for example), the change specifically for display plugins' collapsible buttons in style.qss would still affect them, right?

You can create rules which only affect collapsible buttons within a display plugin. For example, you can name your `CollapsibleWidget` something like `displayCollapsible` and then add something like this to the QSS:

~~~
ignition--gui--CollapsibleWidget#displayCollapsible > QPushButton#collapsibleButton
{
  ...
}
~~~

(I haven't tested this specific rule though)

> I am imagining that the resulting style is somehow the union of the stylesheets ... Or would that stylesheet have to re-specify whatever property I add to style.qss?

I'm not sure if I understand correctly, but QSS (in theory) works like CSS, so it should follow most [specificity](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Specificity) rules (i.e. the last declaration overrides previous ones).

If your question is about how ign-gui allows specifying a new `style.qss`, the new QSS file completely overwrites the default one, so if you want to keep some setting the same as in the default QSS, you need to copy it over to your file.
content.html:
if a .config xml file has a stylesheet specified in it (with properties for collapsibleButton, for example), the change specifically for display plugins' collapsible buttons in style.qss would still affect them, right?

You can create rules which only affect collapsible buttons within a display plugin. For example, you can name your CollapsibleWidget something like displayCollapsible and then add something like this to the QSS:

ignition--gui--CollapsibleWidget#displayCollapsible > QPushButton#collapsibleButton
{
  ...
}

(I haven't tested this specific rule though)

I am imagining that the resulting style is somehow the union of the stylesheets ... Or would that stylesheet have to re-specify whatever property I add to style.qss?

I'm not sure if I understand correctly, but QSS (in theory) works like CSS, so it should follow most specificity rules (i.e. the last declaration overrides previous ones).

If your question is about how ign-gui allows specifying a new style.qss, the new QSS file completely overwrites the default one, so if you want to keep some setting the same as in the default QSS, you need to copy it over to your file.

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw: it doesn't seem that the styles are merged, so if I have understood correctly, specifying it in the style.qss \(with e.g. `border: none`\) instead of calling `setFlat(true)` will mean that anyone that is specifying a stylesheet in the .config will additionally have to specify that display widgets' collapsible buttons should look flat. that seems like it will result in style duplication that we maybe don’t want?
content.html: it doesn't seem that the styles are merged, so if I have understood correctly, specifying it in the style.qss (with e.g. border: none) instead of calling setFlat(true) will mean that anyone that is specifying a stylesheet in the .config will additionally have to specify that display widgets' collapsible buttons should look flat. that seems like it will result in style duplication that we maybe don’t want?

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw: A question about that route \(having not worked with stylesheets before\): if a .config xml file has a stylesheet specified in it \(with properties for `collapsibleButton`, for example\), the change specifically for display plugins' collapsible buttons in style.qss would still affect them, right? \(that’s what I want; I am imagining that the resulting style is somehow the union of the stylesheets.\) Or would that stylesheet have to re-specify whatever property I add to style.qss?
content.html: A question about that route (having not worked with stylesheets before): if a .config xml file has a stylesheet specified in it (with properties for collapsibleButton, for example), the change specifically for display plugins' collapsible buttons in style.qss would still affect them, right? (that’s what I want; I am imagining that the resulting style is somehow the union of the stylesheets.) Or would that stylesheet have to re-specify whatever property I add to style.qss?

pull_request.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

pullrequest.title: Make collapsible button of relevant display plugins "flat"

content.raw: I suggest you take a look into doing this using QSS instead. [Here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/src/4d33454508fe7e5f2556165a6c58254dfb8503ba/include/ignition/gui/style.qss?fileviewer=file-view-default#style.qss-181)'s all the default QSS for the collapsible button at the moment. In general, we try to use QSS instead of hardcoded options on ign-gui to be more consistent (it's a pain when they conflict). You may be able to achieve this by giving the display plugin a custom ID and referencing its child collapsible button in the QSS.
content.html: I suggest you take a look into doing this using QSS instead. Here's all the default QSS for the collapsible button at the moment. In general, we try to use QSS instead of hardcoded options on ign-gui to be more consistent (it's a pain when they conflict). You may be able to achieve this by giving the display plugin a custom ID and referencing its child collapsible button in the QSS.
